question: Can both tuberculosis and mycobacterial diseases affect multiple parts of the body?
generated_answer: Yes, both tuberculosis and mycobacterial diseases can affect multiple parts of the body. Tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affects the lungs but can also affect other organs such as the brain, spine, kidneys, and bones. Mycobacterial diseases, which include tuberculosis and other infections caused by different Mycobacterium species, can also affect various parts of the body, depending on the specific type of mycobacterium and the individual's immune response.
ground_truth_answer: Yes, both tuberculosis and mycobacterial diseases can affect multiple parts of the body. While TB usually affects the lungs (pulmonary disease), it can also spread to other parts of the body including the brain, kidneys, and spine. Similarly, mycobacterial diseases can affect various parts of the body, as evidenced by the research showing that patients with IFN-γR1 gene mutations are susceptible to severe forms of mycobacterial disease throughout their body due to their compromised immune response to mycobacteria.
